If the patient has a low-lying placenta or a placenta previa, discharge home on pelvic rest is likely appropriate after ensuring clinical stability of the pregnant person and fetus. Patients should be counseled to return for any contractions or vaginal bleeding. If a new vasa previa is identified, the patient should be admitted for inpatient monitoring, given corticosteroids, and undergo C-section at 34 to 37 weeks because this condition carries higher fetal risks than placenta previa or low-lying placenta.        

Diagnosis and management of stable patients with placenta and vasa previa are detailed in the table below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Transvaginal ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Digital cervix exam:
Incorrect: Digital cervix exams are absolutely contraindicated in placenta or vasa previa because the exam may disrupt the placenta or umbilical vessels and cause or worsen bleeding. Cervical dilation should be assessed visually in these patients with a sterile speculum exam. 
❌ Discharge home with pelvic rest and return precautions:
Incorrect: This patient had a placenta previa at 20 weeks; however, she has not yet had a follow-up scan to determine if the previa has resolved or converted to a vasa previa. Therefore, a transvaginal ultrasound is the best next step, as it will provide more context for her bleeding and the management decisions. 
❌ Inpatient monitoring and corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Inpatient monitoring and corticosteroids are appropriate for patients with a vasa previa. This patient had a placenta previa at 20 weeks. However, she has not yet had a follow-up scan to determine if the previa has resolved or converted to a vasa previa. Therefore, a transvaginal ultrasound is the best next step, as it will provide more context for her bleeding and the management decisions. 
❌ C-section:
Incorrect: Emergent C-section is indicated when the patient or fetus is unstable. This patient has stable vital signs and the NST is reassuring, so urgent delivery is not appropriate at this time.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 2 at 36 weeks of gestational age, presents to discuss her mode of delivery. Her first delivery was an uncomplicated cesarean birth at 41 weeks for arrest of dilation during labor 5 years ago. This was followed by a spontaneous miscarriage at 10 weeks that was managed with a dilation and curettage 3 years ago. Her third pregnancy was complicated by an acute placental abruption following a motor vehicle accident that resulted in an emergent cesarean birth at 25 weeks of gestational age 23 months ago. No prior surgical records are available. The current pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Past medical history is also notable for a hysteroscopic myomectomy of a small submucosal leiomyoma that was causing heavy menstrual bleeding 7 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits and body mass index is 26 kg/m2. On abdominal exam, two low transverse skin incisions are noted, and the fundal height is 36 cm. Obstetric ultrasound shows a single viable fetus in the vertex presentation with a normal fetal heart rate, posterior placenta, and adequate amniotic fluid. Which of the following is a contraindication to a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC)?

choices.text: History of emergent preterm cesarean birth
History of cesarean birth for arrest of labor

questions.solution:
This patient has a history of cesarean birth performed emergently in the second trimester. These deliveries may be performed through a classical uterine incision, a vertical incision through the strong upper contractile fibers of the uterus. These incisions are associated with higher rates of uterine rupture than transverse incisions which are made in the lower uterine segment. For this reason, patients with a history of emergent preterm cesarean birth should not attempt a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) unless the operative report from the delivery in question can be reviewed and it confirms a low transverse uterine incision.        

If operative reports are unavailable for review, the history can be used to assess whether a low transverse uterine incision is likely. In the modern era, classical uterine incisions are typically reserved for patients delivering in the second or early third trimester, especially under emergent circumstances. They may also be used in patients with large fibroids in the lower uterine segment.   

Option Analysis

✅ History of emergent preterm cesarean birth:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Two prior cesarean birth :
Incorrect: A TOLAC is generally appropriate for patients like this one with a history of one or two prior cesarean births. They are contraindicated for patients with more than two prior cesarean births due to the increased risk of uterine rupture. 
❌ History of myomectomy:
Incorrect: Myomectomy of a large intramural uterine fibroid is a contraindication to TOLAC because full-thickness incisions increase the risk of uterine rupture. Smaller submucosal fibroids, like in the vignette, can be removed hysteroscopically without significant incisions into the myometrium and thus are not a contraindication to TOLAC.  
❌ History of cesarean birth for arrest of labor :
Incorrect: A history of cesarean birth for arrest of labor reduces a patient’s chance of a successful vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC), but it is not a contraindication to TOLAC. These patients should be counseled appropriately. 
❌ Time interval since last birth :
Incorrect: TOLAC is not recommended with close interval deliveries occurring within 18 months of each other.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 35 weeks of gestational age, presents to discuss her mode of delivery. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she has no concerns today. Her first cesarean birth was performed for arrest of dilation at 7 cm and complicated by postpartum endomyometritis. During her second pregnancy, she had an anterior placenta previa and underwent a repeat cesarean birth that was then complicated by a postpartum hemorrhage requiring a blood transfusion. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam is unremarkable with a normal fundal height. Obstetric ultrasound shows an anterior placenta 25 mm from the internal cervical os, a single deepest vertical pocket of 2.4 cm, and a single viable fetus in the vertex presentation with a fetal heart rate of 150 bpm. Which of the following is the best reason to recommend a planned repeat cesarean birth (PRCB) over a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) for this patient?

choices.text: VBAC would be associated with higher rates of postpartum hemorrhage than PRCB.
VBAC would be associated with higher rates of postpartum endomyometritis than PRCB.
She is at increased risk for uterine rupture with TOLAC
She is at increased risk for abnormal placentation in future pregnancies

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of two prior cesarean births, is presenting to discuss the risks and benefits associated with a planned repeat cesarean birth (PRCB) versus a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC). For patients without a contraindication to TOLAC, a successful vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC) is associated with the lowest risks. However, a PRCB is associated with lower risks than a failed TOLAC requiring a c-section. For this reason, the choice of delivery method should be based on the chance for a successful VBAC, patient preferences, and risk tolerance. TOLAC is favored when the chance of successful VBAC is > 60% while PRCB is favored when the chance of successful VBAC is < 60%. This patient has a history of cesarean birth performed due to arrest of labor, which decreases her chance of a successful VBAC; therefore, PRBC should be recommended.        

Additionally, this patient has not had a prior vaginal birth, which would have increased her chance of VBAC. Given these factors, PRCB may be a more prudent choice to minimize her risks. It should be noted, however, that neither of these factors are contraindications to TOLAC in a well-counseled patient who desires TOLAC.        

Risks, benefits, and specific patient factors that favor a particular delivery route are detailed in the table above.  



Option Analysis

✅ Decreased chance of successful VBAC:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ VBAC would be associated with higher rates of postpartum hemorrhage than PRCB.:
Incorrect: Overall, the risk of hemorrhage is higher in patients undergoing a scheduled repeat cesarean birth than those attempting a TOLAC because the risk of hemorrhage is lower in the large proportion of individuals who do have a successful vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC). 
❌ VBAC would be associated with higher rates of postpartum endomyometritis than PRCB.:
Incorrect: Overall, the risk of infection is higher in patients undergoing a scheduled repeat cesarean birth than in those attempting a TOLAC, because the risk of endomyometritis is lower in the large proportion of individuals who have a successful vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC). 
❌ She is at increased risk for uterine rupture with TOLAC:
Incorrect: A scheduled repeat cesarean birth significantly reduces the incidence of uterine rupture. However, a history of two prior cesarean births is not a contraindication to TOLAC. 
❌ She is at increased risk for abnormal placentation in future pregnancies:
Incorrect: The risk of abnormal placentation in future pregnancies is increased with each additional cesarean birth. Therefore, the risk of abnormal placentation is lower in patients with a successful vaginal birth after cesarean.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 28 weeks of estimated gestational age (EGA), presents for a routine antenatal appointment. She has no vaginal bleeding, cramping, loss of fluid, or decreased fetal movement. Her initial prenatal blood work revealed an A-negative blood type, mild anemia, positive IgG antibodies to Rhesus D, rubella, and varicella, and negative syphilis, hepatitis B, and HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) screening tests. Her first pregnancy was complicated by a chronic placental abruption. Vital signs today are within normal limits, and she appears well, with a gravid abdomen and a fundal height of 26 cm. Labs today show an anti-D antibody titer of 1:32. Doppler velocimetry shows peak blood flow velocity through the middle cerebral artery (MCA) two times above the median and normal flow through the umbilical arteries and ductus venosus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Fetal steroids and delivery at 32 to 34 weeks EGA
Serial MCA Doppler studies and anticipated delivery at 37 weeks EGA
Fetal steroids and delivery within 48 hours

questions.solution:
An elevation in peak systolic blood flow velocity through the middle cerebral artery (MCA) > 1.5 times the median suggests moderate to severe fetal anemia. When increased MCA velocity is observed, percutaneous umbilical (cord) blood sampling (PUBS) is indicated. This procedure uses ultrasound guidance to insert a needle into the umbilical cord to obtain a fetal blood sample for hematocrit testing. If PUBS confirms severe anemia, then intrauterine fetal blood transfusions through the umbilical cord are indicated to prolong the pregnancy, ideally through 32 to 34 weeks EGA.

Anti-D antibodies in Rh-negative pregnant patients can attack Rh-positive fetal erythrocytes, leading to severe anemia. A fetus is at greater risk for hemolytic disease when more maternal antibodies are present. Therefore, patients with antibody titers above 1:8 should be screened for fetal anemia with MCA Doppler velocimetry. As anemia worsens, the peak systolic velocity of blood flowing through the MCA increases due to decreased blood viscosity, increased cardiac output, and the preferential shunting of blood to the brain.

The patient in the vignette is only 28 weeks EGA, with high Rh D titers and increased flow through the MCA; PUBS to assess the level of anemia followed by a possible intrauterine fetal blood transfusion is indicated.    

Option Analysis

✅ Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intrauterine fetal blood transfusion:
Incorrect: Blood flow velocity greater than 1.5 times the median through the MCA is a sign of moderate to severe fetal anemia, and percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS) is indicated to assess fetal hematocrit. If a critically low hematocrit is confirmed, a fetal blood transfusion may be appropriate. 
❌ Fetal steroids and delivery at 32 to 34 weeks EGA:
Incorrect: Steroids with delivery at 32 to 34 weeks EGA is indicated in the setting of severe fetal anemia, which is suggested by elevated peak systolic MCA velocity and confirmed with a low fetal hematocrit on a percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS). 
❌ Serial MCA Doppler studies and anticipated delivery at 37 weeks EGA:
Incorrect: This plan would be appropriate for patients with normal MCA Doppler studies, which indicates a lack of moderate to severe fetal anemia. When blood flow velocity is greater than 1.5 times the median through the MCA, percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS) is indicated to assess fetal hematocrit. 
❌ Fetal steroids and delivery within 48 hours:
Incorrect: The risks associated with preterm birth before 32 weeks EGA are significant. It is prudent to first assess fetal hematocrit through percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS) in patients with elevated MCA Dopplers. If severe anemia is confirmed, the preferred management is to try and extend the pregnancy to at least 32 weeks with intrauterine fetal blood transfusions.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 33 weeks of estimated gestational age (EGA), presents to Labor & Delivery Triage with pelvic cramping for the past 4 hours that has not resolved with rest and hydration. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and the patient has no major medical problems. Her first pregnancy was complicated by preterm labor at 36 weeks, which resulted in a spontaneous vaginal delivery 24 hours later. She takes a prenatal vitamin daily. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mmHg. On exam, the cervix is 4 cm dilated and 50% effaced, at -3 cm station. Urine culture from the initial antenatal visit was positive for group B Streptococcus (GBS), though the patient has not been tested again since that time. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial medication regimen for this patient?

choices.text: Dexamethasone, indomethacin, magnesium sulfate, and penicillin

questions.solution:
This patient who presents with cramping and cervical dilation of ≥ 3 cm between 20 and 37 weeks EGA, is in preterm labor. Management of preterm labor depends on the gestational age and is detailed in the table above. At 33 weeks EGA, the most appropriate initial medication regimen includes betamethasone, nifedipine, and penicillin. A neonatal consult is also recommended. 

There are 4 primary categories of medications to consider for preterm labor patients. First, steroids are indicated in all patients in preterm labor with a potentially viable fetus to promote fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intracranial hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), and death. Options include betamethasone and dexamethasone. 

The second category is tocolytics. These medications are used to slow contractions for up to 48 hours in patients with a potentially viable fetus at < 34 weeks EGA to get the maximum benefit from the course of steroids. The primary tocolytics used are indomethacin and nifedipine; terbutaline can also be considered. Importantly, indomethacin is contraindicated after 32 weeks due to the risk of constriction of the ductus arteriosus in utero, oligohydramnios, and NEC. 

The final two categories are magnesium sulfate, which is indicated to reduce the risk of cerebral palsy in patients < 32 weeks, and GBS prophylaxis, which is indicated for all patients who have an unknown GBS status or are known to be positive.    

Option Analysis

✅ Betamethasone, nifedipine, and penicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dexamethasone, indomethacin, magnesium sulfate, and penicillin:
Incorrect: This regimen would be appropriate for patients less than 32 weeks EGA. This patient is 33 weeks and therefore should receive nifedipine instead of indomethacin for tocolysis, and magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection is no longer indicated. 
❌ Betamethasone, indomethacin, and magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: This patient is 33 weeks and therefore, should receive nifedipine instead of indomethacin for tocolysis, and magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection is no longer indicated. Additionally, GBS prophylaxis with penicillin is indicated given the positive urine culture from earlier in the pregnancy. 
❌ Prednisolone, nifedipine, and penicillin:
Incorrect: Prednisolone is not used for fetal maturation because it is inactivated by placental enzymes. Instead, betamethasone or dexamethasone are used for this indication. 
❌ Dexamethasone, nifedipine, and magnesium sulfate :
Incorrect: This patient is GBS positive based on positive urine culture result. Therefore, GBS prophylaxis with penicillin is indicated. Additionally, magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection is not indicated at or beyond 32 weeks EGA.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0101, at 36 weeks of estimated gestational age (EGA), presents after experiencing a large gush of fluid from the vagina 30 minutes ago. She reports no contractions, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. Her first pregnancy was complicated by a spontaneous preterm birth at 32 weeks EGA three years ago. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin, and she has no allergies. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. During the speculum examination, straw-colored clear fluid accumulates within the posterior speculum blade. The cervix is visually 3 cm dilated, and a pulsating purple mass is visible within the cervical canal. The fetal heart rate is in the 130s, with moderate variability and recurrent spontaneous variable decelerations to the 60s. No contractions are noted on tocometry. The patient’s group B Streptococcus (GBS) status is unknown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Manual elevation of the fetal head
Immediate transfer for emergency cesarean delivery
Fine needle aspiration of the mass
Expectant management, steroids, and GBS prophylaxis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM), which is defined as the rupture of fetal membranes before the onset of labor in a patient who is < 37 weeks EGA), complicated by an umbilical cord prolapse. Cord prolapse occurs when the umbilical cord slips between an unengaged fetus and the cervix into, and sometimes through, the cervical canal. This is a life-threatening emergency for the fetus, as the umbilical cord can easily become compressed or lacerated. When cord prolapse is detected, the examiner should immediately insert their hand into the patient’s vagina and manually elevate the fetal head off the umbilical cord. Elevation of the fetus should continue until the neonate is delivered by emergency cesarean.         

Cord prolapse can be detected visually or on a digital exam. The cord appears as a thick, pulsating, cord-like structure, or mass within the cervical canal. The fetal heart rate pattern may show variable decelerations or bradycardia. The pregnant person does not develop any symptoms with a cord prolapse. Cord prolapse is one of the obstetric emergencies that should always be considered in patients with ruptured membranes.   

Option Analysis

✅ Manual elevation of the fetal head:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bedside ultrasound:
Incorrect: Bedside ultrasound for fetal presentation and assessment of amniotic fluid volume is appropriate in a stable patient diagnosed with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM). However, this patient has a prolapsed umbilical cord, which is an obstetric emergency, and the fetus must be immediately elevated off the cord and the patient taken for an emergency cesarean. 
❌ Immediate transfer for emergency cesarean delivery:
Incorrect: This patient does require an emergency cesarean delivery for a prolapsed umbilical cord. However, before transferring the patient to the operating room, the fetal head must be manually elevated off the cord and maintained in that position until delivery. 
❌ Fine needle aspiration of the mass :
Incorrect: The pulsating mass is the umbilical cord, which should not be sampled, as this may result in unnecessary fetal bleeding. The fetal head should be manually elevated off the cord and the patient should be transferred to the operating room for an emergent cesarean delivery. 
❌ Expectant management, steroids, and GBS prophylaxis:
Incorrect: This patient has a prolapsed umbilical cord, requiring an emergency cesarean delivery rather than expectant management, and the first step is to elevate the fetal head off the cord.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 26 weeks of gestational age presents with a gush of fluid from the vagina 1 hour ago. She has no contractions or decreased fetal movement. She is healthy, without any underlying medical problems, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mmHg. The patient appears fatigued and anxious. The uterus is gravid and moderately tender to palpation. The cervix is closed on inspection, and there is a small amount of fluid in the vaginal vault. A vaginal fluid sample reveals a pH of 7.2 with a crystalline pattern on microscopy. Maternal-fetal cardiotocographic monitoring shows moderate variability and no decelerations. Which of the following would be an indication for delivery instead of inpatient expectant management?

choices.text: Fetal heart rate of 165 beats per minute
Maternal pulse of 110 beats per minute
Delivery is already indicated, and no further findings are necessary

questions.solution:
In a patient presenting with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM) and a fever, suspicion must be high for a possible intraamniotic infection (IAI), which would necessitate IV antibiotics and delivery. A presumptive diagnosis of IAI can be made in patients with a single temperature ≥ 39.0 °C or with a temperature between 38.0 °C and 38.9 °C if at least one of the following clinical factors is also present:    
  •  fetal tachycardia > 160 beats per minute (bpm)  
  •  maternal leukocytosis > 15,000/mm3     
  •  purulent fluid from the cervical os  

Although they are not part of the diagnostic criteria, maternal tachycardia and uterine tenderness are commonly encountered with IAIs and support the diagnosis.       

PPROM refers to the rupture of fetal membranes prior to the onset of labor and occurring 37 weeks before estimated gestational age (EGA). It is diagnosed by visualizing amniotic fluid coming from the cervix, pooling of fluid in the vaginal vault, and/or by the presence of ferning on microscopic examination of the vaginal fluid. Once a diagnosis of PPROM is made, the patient must be evaluated for signs and symptoms suggesting IAI, which includes assessing the fetal heart rate and sending a complete blood count. It is also good practice to send a rectovaginal culture for Group B Streptococcus and perform a limited obstetric ultrasound to assess the fetal presentation and amniotic fluid volume.   

Option Analysis

✅ Fetal heart rate of 165 beats per minute:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ White blood cell (WBC) count of 13,500/mm3:
Incorrect: Intraamniotic infection (IAI) is an indication for delivery. Patients who have a temperature between 38.0°C and 38.9°C and at least one additional factor can meet criteria for IAI. Maternal WBC > 15,000/mm3 would meet this criterion and be an indication for IAI and delivery. 
❌ Blood-tinged amniotic fluid:
Incorrect: While bleeding should always heighten suspicion for a possible placental abruption, light bleeding in the setting of cervical dilation is common (i.e., “bloody show”), and it is not an indication for delivery, especially at only 26 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA) with reassuring fetal monitoring. Purulent discharge, on the other hand, suggests intraamniotic infection, which is an indication for delivery. 
❌ Maternal pulse of 110 beats per minute:
Incorrect: Although maternal tachycardia is commonly seen in patients with an intraamniotic infection (which is an indication for delivery), maternal tachycardia is not one of the criteria used to diagnose the condition.  
❌ Delivery is already indicated, and no further findings are necessary:
Incorrect:  Intraamniotic infection (IAI) is an indication for delivery, but this patient does not yet meet criteria for presumed IAI.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 34 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA), presents for routine antenatal care. Her last appointment was 4 weeks ago, and she is up-to-date on all recommended screenings and interventions. She is concerned that while she feels at least 10 movements in the hour following dinner, she no longer feels much fetal movement during other parts of the day, which is a change for her. Also, several days ago, she experienced irregular contractions over 4 hours that resolved with oral hydration and rest. She has not had loss of fluid or vaginal bleeding. Obstetric history is notable for a single uncomplicated vaginal delivery at term 2 years ago. She takes a prenatal vitamin daily. Pre-pregnancy body mass index was 23 kg/m2, and she has gained 31 lb. (13.6 kg) during this pregnancy. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 136/84 mmHg. On exam, the fundal height measures 36 cm, and the fetal heart rate is 135/min on handheld Doppler. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CBC, CMP, and urine protein-to-creatinine ratio

questions.solution:
Patients like this one, who present with decreased or atypical fetal movement, should undergo additional tests for fetal well-being, such as a complete biophysical profile (BPP) or a non-stress test (NST), or NST with amniotic fluid volume (AFV) assessment (together known as a modified BPP). 

Patients should be counseled on fetal movement awareness and instructed to notify their provider if fetal movement seems decreased or atypical (i.e., change from baseline). Numerous fetal movement awareness methods have been described (e.g., at least 10 movements should be appreciated in 2 hours at least once per day). However, none are a superior way to assess fetal movements. Additionally, there are no clearly established quantitative thresholds that can accurately predict fetal compromise. Therefore, all patients reporting atypical fetal movement should be immediately evaluated with more reliable tests of fetal well-being. 

An NST evaluates the fetal heart rate and contraction patterns. A modified BPP includes an NST plus an assessment of the AFV, which, when adequate, provides additional confirmation of fetal well-being. A complete BPP also involves the direct sonographic visualization of distinct types of fetal movements. A reassuring modified or complete BPP indicates a low risk of stillbirth within the next 7 days.   

Option Analysis

✅ Non-stress test:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Pelvic exam:
Incorrect: The contractions the patient described are consistent with Braxton-Hicks contractions, which do not represent true labor. The contractions resolved spontaneously several days ago, and she has no vaginal bleeding or loss of fluid, so reassurance regarding the contractions is appropriate. A non-stress test or biophysical profile is the best next step for a patient with decreased fetal movement. 
❌ Growth ultrasound:
Incorrect: The patient’s fundal height is within 2 cm of her EGA, and she has no risk factors for abnormal fetal growth (e.g., gestational diabetes, hypertensive disorders, obesity, autoimmune disease). A non-stress test or biophysical profile is the best next step for a patient with decreased fetal movement. 
❌ CBC, CMP, and urine protein-to-creatinine ratio:
Incorrect: These lab tests are part of the evaluation for hypertensive disorders of pregnancy and should be ordered in patients with blood pressure ≥ 140 mmHg systolic and/or ≥ 90 mmHg diastolic; the patient in the vignette does not meet these thresholds. 
❌ Nutritional counseling:
Incorrect: Patients with a normal prepregnancy BMI (18.5 to 24.9 kg/m2) should gain 25 to 35 lb. (11.5 to 16.0 kg) throughout pregnancy. This patient’s weight gain is normal, and there is no indication that she has another condition, such as gestational diabetes, that would warrant nutritional counseling.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 34 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA) dated by a first trimester ultrasound, with a dichorionic twin gestation and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), presents for routine antenatal care. She is asymptomatic. The anatomy ultrasound was normal at 20 weeks, the patient was diagnosed with GDM on routine screening at 28 weeks, and she has declined all aneuploidy screening. Her history is notable for one prior vaginal delivery, factor V Leiden mutation, and influenza in the first trimester that resolved with supportive care after several days. She takes prenatal vitamins, enoxaparin, and metformin. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 136/84 mmHg. On exam, the abdomen is non-tender, and the fundal height is 37 cm. A review of her glucose log shows good control over the past week. Results of routine growth scans are shown in the table. Which of the following from the patient’s history is responsible for twin A’s estimated fetal weight (EFW)? 

 Twin      26 weeks      30 weeks      34 weeks     
 A      19th percentile      15th percentile      8th percentile     
 B      22nd percentile      18th percentile      17th percentile
questions.solution:
Fetal growth restriction (FGR) is defined as a fetus with an estimated fetal weight (EFW) or an abdominal circumference (AC) below the 10th percentile for the EGA. In the vignette, twin A has an EFW at the 8th percentile at 34 weeks, which meets criteria for FGR. In this situation, the most probable cause is multiple gestation.

There are numerous other causes of FGR. Fetal causes include genetic and structural anomalies and congenital TORCH infections. These causes tend to result in more severe growth restriction, which is often diagnosed before 32 weeks. Additionally, maternal and placental conditions that impact the blood flow to an otherwise normal fetus can also lead to FGR, including chronic placental abruption, inadequate availability of nutrients for the fetus (e.g., poor maternal intake, malabsorptive syndromes), and any chronic disorder with a vascular component, such as chronic hypertension, long-standing pre-gestational diabetes, kidney disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, and antiphospholipid syndrome. In these cases, the FGR is often less severe and frequently develops later in pregnancy. One notable exception is pregnancy-induced hypertension, which is a common cause of early-onset FGR.       

Option Analysis

✅ Multiple gestation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Aneuploidy:
Incorrect: Aneuploidy tends to result in early-onset fetal growth restriction (FGR) (i.e., before 32 weeks EGA) and fetal anomalies identified on the routine mid-pregnancy ultrasound. Diagnosis of FGR at 34 weeks in an anatomically normal fetus, like in the vignette, is not likely due to aneuploidy. 
❌ Gestational diabetes:
Incorrect: Gestational diabetes tends to result in macrosomia rather than fetal growth restriction (FGR). FGR could be a potential complication of vascular disease due to long-standing, poorly controlled pre-gestational diabetes. 
❌ First-trimester infection:
Incorrect: Some first-trimester infections can result in congenital infection of the fetus and fetal growth restriction (FGR), including cytomegalovirus (CMV), toxoplasmosis, rubella, and varicella. Influenza is not strongly associated with FGR and tends to only affect patients who become severely ill, which did not occur in this vignette. 
❌ Factor V Leiden mutation:
Incorrect: Unlike acquired thrombophilias, such as antiphospholipid syndrome, inherited thrombophilias, including Factor V Leiden (FVL), have not been proven to cause fetal growth restriction (FGR).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, presents for an ultrasound at 31 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA). The pregnancy is complicated by Turner syndrome and fetal growth restriction (FGR). The patient has no contractions, vaginal bleeding, loss of fluid, or decreased fetal movement. Past medical history is notable for a single uncomplicated vaginal birth at term three years ago, and the patient is taking a prenatal vitamin. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 114/73 mmHg. On exam, the abdomen is non-tender, and the fundal height is 28 cm. Today’s ultrasound shows an estimated fetal weight (EFW) at the 4th percentile, a head circumference (HC) at the 7th percentile, and an abdominal circumference (AC) at the 3rd percentile. Color Doppler velocimetry of the umbilical artery (UA Doppler) shows forward blood flow during fetal systole and no flow by the end of diastole. Which of the following is the most appropriate management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Corticosteroids, serial UA Doppler exams 2 to 3 times weekly, with delivery at 33 to 34 weeks
Serial UA Doppler exams every 1 to 2 weeks, with delivery at 38 to 39 weeks
Serial UA Doppler exams once weekly, with delivery at 37 weeks
Hospital admission, corticosteroids, and delivery in 48 hours

questions.solution:
Fetal growth restriction (FGR), defined as an estimated fetal weight (EFW) or abdominal circumference (AC) below the 10th percentile for EGA, is often associated with increased placental resistance. For this reason, all patients diagnosed with FGR should be screened with an umbilical artery (UA) Doppler assessment. Absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), as seen in this vignette, is associated with worsening placental function. These patients should be followed more closely with serial UA Dopplers 2 to 3 times per week, and they should be managed with corticosteroids and delivery at 33 to 34 weeks EGA.

Because the placenta is typically an area of low resistance within fetal circulation, blood should continue to flow forward through the umbilical arteries during both fetal systole and diastole. As placental resistance increases, blood flow during fetal diastole slows down (decreased end-diastolic flow). With severe disease, flow may completely stop during diastole (AEDF) or even reverse (reversed end-diastolic flow [REDF]). This indicates poor placental function that will compromise fetal well-being.

In addition to serial UA Doppler assessments, all patients with FGR should undergo serial growth scans and regular antenatal fetal surveillance (to ensure fetal well-being). Further management is then based on the results of UA Doppler screening results and is summarized in the table above.   

Option Analysis

✅ Corticosteroids, serial UA Doppler exams 2 to 3 times weekly, with delivery at 33 to 34 weeks :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Serial UA Doppler exams every 1 to 2 weeks, with delivery at 38 to 39 weeks :
Incorrect: This management plan is appropriate for patients with an EFW between the 3rd and 10th percentile with normal UA Doppler. The patient in the vignette has absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), which is abnormal and indicates more severe uteroplacental insufficiency. 
❌ Serial UA Doppler exams once weekly, with delivery at 37 weeks:
Incorrect: This management plan is appropriate for patients with EFW below the third percentile or patients with FGR and decreased end diastolic flow (EDF). In the vignette, the patient has absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), which indicates more severe disease and requires more frequent monitoring. 
❌ Hospital admission, corticosteroids, and delivery in 48 hours:
Incorrect: This management plan is appropriate for patients with reversed end-diastolic flow (REDF) on UA Doppler, which indicates severe resistance within the placenta. In the vignette, this patient has absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), which indicates less severe disease, so continued monitoring until 33 to 34 weeks is appropriate. 
❌ Hospital admission for immediate delivery :
Incorrect: Immediate delivery at 31 weeks is typically reserved for patients clinically unstable patients and those with non-reassuring tests of fetal well-being, such as a non-stress test or biophysical profile. Abnormal UA Doppler assessments indicate poor placental function but are not a test of current fetal well-being.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 22-year-old primigravid woman is brought to the hospital at 30 weeks of estimated gestational age (EGA) after being thrown down the stairs during an argument with her partner 45 minutes ago, which resulted in direct abdominal trauma. Shortly after, she developed severe cramping abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Currently, she feels dizzy and lightheaded, and she is worried about the pregnancy. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 94/56 mmHg. On examination, the patient is alert, oriented, and conversant, though tearful. Bruising is noted on the left cheek, both wrists, and the abdomen. The uterus is firm and tender to palpation. After removing a grapefruit-sized clot from the vagina, a speculum exam shows active bleeding from a visually closed cervix. While applying the maternal-fetal monitors, the fetal heart rate is noted to be in the 90s/min, which does not change despite several changes in maternal position and supplemental oxygen. IV fluids are initiated, laboratory studies are sent, and blood products are ordered. Findings from the patient’s antenatal record are shown in the table below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Study      Result     
 Blood type      A negative     
 Antibody screen      Negative     
 Placental location      Fundal     
 Anatomy ultrasound at 20 weeks EGA      Normal
questions.solution:
Placental abruption refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall during pregnancy. As the placenta separates, both maternal and fetal vessels at the placental interface bleed. Depending on the size of the abruption, this bleeding can be life-threatening for both the pregnant person and their fetus. Therefore, if either the pregnant person or their fetus becomes unstable due to blood loss from a placental abruption, emergency cesarian birth is indicated to control the hemorrhage. 

The classic presentation of abruption is painful vaginal bleeding in the setting of risk factors, non-reassuring fetal monitoring, and a hypertonic uterus. A placental abruption can be diagnosed clinically, and treatment should not be delayed for additional testing in an unstable patient. Initial management efforts should be directed at stabilizing both the pregnant person and the fetus. This includes addressing the airway, breathing, and circulation of the pregnant person, and delivering the fetus to stop the hemorrhage and allowing for direct respiratory and circulatory resuscitation of the child. 

As an important aside, intimate partner violence (IPV) often begins or escalates during pregnancy. Screening for IPV is critical during pregnancy, and if found or suspected, appropriate support must be provided.

P.S. If you or someone you know has experienced intimate partner violence, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope for Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources       

Option Analysis

✅ Emergency cesarean birth:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sonographic assessment of the placenta:
Incorrect: This patient can be clinically diagnosed with placental abruption, and both she and the fetus are unstable. The only way to control the hemorrhage is with immediate surgical delivery. Placental ultrasound findings will not change management, so definitive treatment should not be delayed for this test. 
❌ Non-stress test :
Incorrect: A non-stress test is a form of antenatal fetal surveillance that is performed over the course of 20-40 minutes. It is an appropriate way to evaluate fetal well-being in stable patients presenting with a chief concern that suggests abruption. However, this patient and the fetus are unstable requiring emergency cesarean birth. 
❌ Rh immune globulin:
Incorrect: Rh immune globulin is indicated to prevent Rh alloimmunization in Rh-negative individuals exposed to Rh-positive fetal blood. While Rh immune globulin is appropriate for this Rh-negative patient with an abruption, it is not the next immediate step in emergency management, which is delivery. 
❌ Digital cervix exam:
Incorrect: Although a digital cervix exam is typically indicated in pregnant patients with abdominal pain, this patient has a severe placental abruption and requires immediate delivery. With a visually closed cervix on speculum exam, this patient requires cesarean birth.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old primigravid non-binary pregnant person presents to the emergency department at 31 weeks estimated gestational age (EGA) after a motor vehicle accident 45 minutes ago. The patient was a restrained passenger, and the airbag deployed. Since the accident, the patient has developed moderate abdominal cramping and light vaginal bleeding. Fetal movement is normal, and no other symptoms are present. Their past medical history is unremarkable, and the only medication is a daily prenatal vitamin. Their temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/80 mmHg. On examination, the uterus is firm and mildly tender to palpation. A speculum exam shows brown-tinged cervical mucus but no active bleeding. The cervix is 1 cm dilated, thick, and high in the pelvis. Labs are shown in the table below. An ultrasound shows an anterior placenta with a small fluid collection behind its inferior margin. Four hours of cardiotocographic monitoring demonstrates initial high-frequency, low amplitude contractions, but these resolve over time. A repeat cervical exam and ultrasound are unchanged. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Test      Result     
 Hemoglobin      11.3 g/dL     
 Hematocrit      34%     
 Platelets      189,000/mm3     
 Prothrombin time (PT)      12 sec     
 International normalized ratio (INR)      1.1     
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)      30 sec     
 Fibrinogen      345 mg/dL     
 Kleihauer-Betke (KB) test      Negative     
 Blood type      A     
 Rh D      Positive     
 Antibody screen      Negative

choices.text: Admission for close monitoring until planned delivery at 34 weeks

questions.solution:
Placental abruption is clinically diagnosed in pregnant patients presenting with pain and vaginal bleeding after abdominal trauma. Abruption increases the chance of delivery within the next seven days, so preterm patients should be given antenatal corticosteroids to promote fetal maturation. Rh immune globulin is also indicated for Rh-negative individuals. 

Placental abruption is the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, which can lead to life-threatening bleeding for both the pregnant person and their fetus. However, many partial abruptions are small and can stabilize, and they do not require immediate delivery. Therefore, it is important to determine the severity of an abruption, especially in preterm patients, in order to provide the most appropriate management. 

If a complete evaluation (including serial labs, ultrasound, cardiotocographic monitoring, and clinical exams) indicates that both the pregnant person and fetus are stable with no evidence of ongoing bleeding, active labor, or evolving coagulopathy, immediate delivery can be avoided. Because worsening abruptions cause symptoms (e.g. pain and bleeding), stable patients can often be safely managed as outpatients with strict return precautions, close follow-up, regular antenatal fetal surveillance, and delivered in the late preterm or early term periods.   

Option Analysis

✅ Corticosteroids:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rh immune globulin:
Incorrect: This patient is Rh-positive and is therefore not at risk of alloimmunization against the Rh D antigen, even if maternal-fetal hemorrhage occurs. Rh immune globulin is not indicated in Rh-positive patients. 
❌ Delivery:
Incorrect: In patients with suspected placental abruption, delivery is indicated when monitoring is non-reassuring and/or the pregnant person or fetus are hemodynamically unstable due to ongoing bleeding, which is not the case in the vignette. 
❌ Admission for close monitoring until planned delivery at 34 weeks:
Incorrect: Because worsening placental abruption causes symptoms (e.g. pain, bleeding), stable patients with reassuring monitoring and no evidence of labor or ongoing bleeding can typically be managed as outpatients with antenatal fetal surveillance and planned delivery in the late preterm or early term period. 
❌ Prophylactic antibiotics:
Incorrect: Prophylactic antibiotics are not part of the management of placental abruption, the likely diagnosis in the vignette. On the other hand, antibiotics are critical in the management of preterm prelabor rupture of membranes; however, in the vignette, the patient’s membranes are intact.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman at 16 weeks gestational age presents to the emergency department with a single stab wound to the left lower abdominal quadrant. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated to this point. Past medical history is significant for anxiety and depression, managed with sertraline. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 86/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On exam, the patient is conversant, but mildly confused, cold, and pale, with clammy skin. A 3 cm laceration is noted in the left lower abdominal quadrant, that continues to slowly bleed. There is rigidity and significant tenderness to palpation in the lower abdominal quadrants. A pelvic exam reveals blood-tinged discharge, but no active bleeding from the cervix, which is visually closed. A trauma-focused ultrasound shows significant free fluid in the pelvis, and a viable fetus, with the heart rate fluctuating between 100 and 140/min. A CBC, coagulation panel, fibrinogen, and type and screen are sent, and IV fluids are initiated. A review of records shows the patient is Rh-negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Wait for laboratory results to return before proceeding

questions.solution:
This pregnant trauma patient presents with signs of hemorrhagic shock, including tachycardia, hypotension, altered mental status, and cold clammy pale skin. She requires emergent resuscitation and emergency exploratory laparotomy to control the hemorrhage.

Emergency resuscitation should include stabilizing the airway, breathing/ventilation, and circulation as needed. IV access should be obtained with two large bore IV’s, and IV fluids should be initiated. According to trauma guidelines, exploratory laparotomy is indicated in trauma patients with hemodynamic instability, peritonitis, evisceration, impalement, or frank blood coming from the GI tract (e.g., NG tube or rectal examination). 

In pregnancy, penetrating abdominal trauma associated with hemorrhagic shock is concerning for uterine rupture, which can be life-threatening for the pregnant person and the fetus. During pregnancy, the uterus is highly vascularized, and significant bleeding can occur, even if the uterus is not fully penetrated. However, if the membranes are intact, the injury repaired, and the patient stabilized, the pregnancy can continue. Finally, it is also important to give all Rh-negative pregnant people Rh immune globulin to prevent alloimmunization.  

Option Analysis

✅ Exploratory laparotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Wait for laboratory results to return before proceeding:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically unstable with internal bleeding from a suspected uterine rupture due to penetrating trauma. Although lab results will be important in guiding resuscitation management, an exploratory laparotomy should not be delayed because of these results. 
❌ Discuss dilation and evacuation (D&E) :
Incorrect: Due to the mechanism of injury and hemodynamic instability, this patient is at elevated risk of uterine rupture or laceration, which requires emergent exploratory laparotomy. Removing the pregnancy with a D&E will not control the hemorrhage because the bleeding is likely coming from the uterine musculature rather than a placental abruption. 
❌ Admit for 24 hours of surveillance:
Incorrect: 24 hours of surveillance is appropriate for stable patients with risk factors or findings that suggest acute placental abruption. The patient in the vignette is unstable with internal bleeding and requires emergent exploratory laparotomy. 
❌ Administer Rh immune globulin :
Incorrect: Although this patient should receive Rh immune globulin to prevent alloimmunization because she is Rh-negative, this is not the most important next step. Controlling the internal hemorrhage with an emergency exploratory laparotomy is indicated first.
